They will be sentenced on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson, has died at the age of 66. He was nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile. Temperton's career began in the 1970s with Heatwave, where he wrote hits like "Boogie Nights." He later became a key songwriter for Michael Jackson, penning songs for "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," which became some of Jackson's most iconic hits. Temperton's work has been covered by numerous artists, including Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin. He won a Grammy Award and was nominated for two Oscars for his work with Quincy Jones.

Researchers at Swansea University and other institutions have discovered over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" in Acre state, Brazil, which are possibly 2,000 years old. These sites, concealed by rainforest until deforestation, are thought to have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places, possibly similar to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids.  The research suggests that the geoglyphs were built in areas with taller vegetation, unlike other ritual sites, and that the surrounding environment was significantly altered by humans, possibly through the cultivation of economically valuable trees. This suggests a form of "prehistoric supermarket" where humans concentrated on specific forest products.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated Querrey 6-4 6-4 in the first round of the Shanghai Masters. He attributed his subdued performance to fatigue from his recent win at the Japan Open and the travel involved in reaching the tournament.  Kyrgios also mentioned that he had a poor night's sleep and a long journey to the court.

The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine protects against head and neck cancers, including a rise in cases among younger, non-smoking men.  Charities and scientists are urging the Welsh government to expand the HPV vaccination program to include boys, citing the vaccine's effectiveness in preventing cervical cancer and the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases. The Welsh government is currently awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, documented his fight against cancer on social media. He attended his prom for a short time before feeling unwell and had to leave.  He received support from his family, friends, and celebrities like Rangers players and the cast of "Wicked."  Despite his diagnosis, Jak remained positive and continued to enjoy life, visiting hospitals, playing his tuba, and spending time with loved ones.  Sadly, his cancer spread and doctors stopped further treatment.  Jak's family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research in his honor.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a Group D match at the African Cup of Nations. Mohamed Salah set up substitute Abdallah El Said for the winning goal in the 89th minute.  Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside and missed several chances.  Egypt now face Ghana for the top spot in the group, while Uganda are eliminated.

Lancashire County Council has chosen to repurpose the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites for a new railway station. This decision was made after a study by Network Rail, which found the sites suitable for the project. The plan aims to provide Skelmersdale with two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, improving connectivity and potentially expanding in the future. The council is currently acquiring the necessary land for the project.
Police found a large number of plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found injured and dragged through several streets in Hamelin, Germany. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, turned himself in to authorities. The motive for the attack is currently unknown. The police are investigating and have secured the scene.

This study, conducted by Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, examined 4,600 workers and found that women are as likely as men to request a pay rise, but less likely to receive one. The study eliminated the impact of part-time work and found that men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they asked compared to women. The research also debunked the "reticent female" theory, suggesting that women are not reluctant to ask for a raise and that there is no evidence of discrimination against women in this area.  The study also found that younger women are more successful in negotiating their pay and conditions than older women.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years due to a lack of suitable land.  Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, still have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. All council-owned sites have been investigated and found unsuitable due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants.  After the two remaining cemeteries are full, only options like reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be available. The last increase in burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19-22, will feature artists like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean.  The festival is introducing an augmented reality app that provides online information, videos, and interviews to visitors. This app will also allow people around the world to experience the festival's atmosphere and access information, tickets, and interviews.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," a rare condition in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite the rarity of this incident, the BHA is committed to understanding the causes and preventing future occurrences.

A 15-year-old girl was raped by Davina (formerly known as Davina Ayrton), a 34-year-old woman, in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Davina denies the charge and will be sentenced on March 4th. The judge believes she poses a risk to herself and may not appear for court and has remanded her into custody. The case is unusual and difficult. The victim, who was intoxicated, shouted at Ayrton to stop the attack, but her friends were asleep. Ayrton has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer. She confessed to the crime in 2014.

Novak Djokovic lost in the Rio Olympics men's doubles, losing 6-4, 6-4 to Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares. This loss followed his earlier defeat in the singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic had also lost in the Wimbledon singles tournament in July to Sam Querrey.

The Carrbridge event in the Cairngorms will feature over 20 chainsaw carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US.  The competition uses only chainsaws to carve animals and people into logs. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Alun Wyn Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained during a World Cup warm-up. He is expected to return to play in February, with the Six Nations campaign starting on February 7th. Webb has renewed his contract with the Ospreys, his home region, and is committed to playing for Wales.

Two men were arrested near the US-Canada border for attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco.  A third man, Nathan Hall, was apprehended in British Columbia, and a fourth, Kali Henifin, was arrested for planning to pick up the men at the border.  All four individuals face charges of drug possession, distribution, and conspiracy. The incident highlights a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms in the area.

Childline counseled over 4,500 children in the past year about online abuse, a number believed to be much higher. The abuse is causing significant distress and fear for young people, with some as young as seven experiencing torment and humiliation.  Dame Esther Rantzen, president of Childline, emphasizes the severity of cyberbullying and urges adults to intervene to protect children.  The Anti-Bullying Alliance is working with various organizations to combat the issue, and a young person shared their experience of online bullying, highlighting the emotional impact and the difficulty of seeking help.

The passage describes the escalating tensions between Israel and the US over the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.  

* **US abstention from UN resolution:** The US chose to abstain from a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, angering Prime Minister Netanyahu.
* **Netanyahu's response:** Netanyahu summoned ambassadors of the countries that voted in favor of the resolution and took retaliatory actions against several countries.
* **Postponement of settlement vote:** The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing new homes in settlements due to concerns about straining relations with the US ahead of Secretary of State Kerry's speech.
* **Kerry's speech:** Secretary of State Kerry is expected to present his vision for ending the conflict and address criticisms of the Obama administration by Israel.
* **Palestinian Authority's view:** The Palestinian Authority President sees the UN resolution as a step towards a peace conference in France. 


The passage highlights the ongoing conflict and the impact of the US's actions on the situation.

The passage details the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations, including events in Windsor and a series of stamps released to commemorate the occasion.  The Queen's visit to the Royal Mail delivery office marked the 500th anniversary of the postal service and was met with singing from the Royal Mail choir.  Prince William praised the Queen's dedication and service, acknowledging her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch.  He also addressed recent criticism regarding his engagement with royal duties, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but needs time to develop into his role.  The Queen's birthday celebrations also include a plaque unveiling, a beacon lighting ceremony, and a lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama.  The passage also includes criticism from a republican group who believe the Queen's birthday celebrations are excessive and the BBC should have reported the event in a more balanced way.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup.  The Hammers dominated the match, scoring two goals in the first half through Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew.  Despite Cheltenham's strong performance, they were unable to break through the West Ham defense.  The match marked the end of League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, was driving a VW Transporter and failed to see McNicholl, who was riding a motorcycle. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family accepted the accident was a momentary lapse and did not want Werner to go to jail.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, was a prominent fighter in Syria, known for his online presence and involvement in propaganda for the Islamic State group. He was involved in fundraising, video diaries, and "keyhole" tours of fighters' quarters, portraying the jihad as glamorous and noble. Khawaja returned to the UK last year, attempting to conceal his entry and faking his own death. He is now facing a possible life sentence for his role in the conflict. Khawaja is considered a dangerous individual, and his motives for returning to the UK remain unclear.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, has joined Barnsley from Wrexham. He scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, finishing eighth in the table. Jackson is Barnsley's third signing for next season and will fit into their playing style. He turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Bottles of "Vanish" detergent have washed up on Cornish beaches, including Poldhu Cove, after a container ship, the MV Blue Ocean, lost a container during stormy weather in May. The National Trust is clearing the bottles, which are sealed but some are said to have leaked. While the Maritime and Coastguard Agency believes the bottles may be from the lost container, there is no definitive evidence. The impact on marine life is a concern, and the public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles.

A car crash occurred on the A9 near Berriedale, Caithness, at approximately 2:00 PM. The crash resulted in injuries to several people, including the driver. The road was closed and diversions were set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers. He made 14 appearances last season, contributing to their promotion to the Championship. This follows the signing of new contracts by other players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour Party have a history of working together to defeat the government, particularly on Brexit and other issues. However, this cooperation has been strained recently, with the Lib Dems pushing for amendments that Labour is unwilling to support. This has led to accusations of "false hope" from Labour, who believe the Lib Dems are using the situation for political gain. Despite the tensions, both parties are committed to working together on issues they agree on, but the future of their alliance remains uncertain.

This election, defence is a low priority for most political parties.  The UK's military spending is being cut, with the size of the army, navy, and air force being reduced.  The UK is falling behind other nations in defence spending, and the commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defence is not being met.  There is a lack of consensus on the future of the UK's nuclear deterrent, with some parties proposing to scrap it altogether.  The new aircraft carriers are facing staffing issues, and the UK's military is facing a "hollow force" problem.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but the actual cost may be higher due to additional contracts.  The club has been accused of misappropriating funds and is under investigation.  They have made a supplementary tax declaration of £13.5 million to defend their reputation.  Neymar has performed well for Barcelona, scoring seven goals in league and three in Champions League matches.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver, was killed in a car crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway.  Newman also died in the crash. Luciw's family and colleagues call for mandatory medical examinations for older drivers and regular driving tests to ensure safety on the road. They believe that current licensing procedures do not adequately address the potential risks associated with driving at older ages. Age UK emphasizes the importance of older people being able to drive safely for as long as possible.

The independent review of transvaginal mesh implants in Scotland concluded that the procedures should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The report recommended a range of treatments and informed patient choices.  It also called for mandatory reporting of adverse events.  However, the process was criticized for being controversial and lacking consensus, with some members of the review group resigning in protest.  The review has been met with calls for an all-out ban, but the Scottish government does not have the power to implement such a ban.  Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had the implants, and there are over 400 women currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir broke Paula McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. While McColgan had raised concerns about Muir's race meeting the record-breaking criteria, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time will be ratified. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals and is a world-class runner.

William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, finished 12th in the event after a disappointing cross-country performance. Despite a faultless show jumping round, he was hampered by time penalties in the cross-country phase.  Jonty Evans finished ninth for Ireland.

Andy Murray defeated Italian Fabio Fognini in a tense match that went to a fourth set tiebreaker. Murray won the match 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round.  Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week of the tournament, defeating Maria Sakkari 6-4 6-1.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven. Police found people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was served until 4:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined Colleen O'Neill (£3,000) and James Thomas (£1,000) for allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern about the bar's poor management and O'Neill's poor record.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, stated that the election should be a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. He defended his comments about potentially working with the SDLP, stating that he believes they would be better suited to governing than Sinn Féin or the DUP. He emphasized his confidence in his party's position and the support he received in unionist areas. The party's manifesto, "Real Partnership," focuses on issues like waiting lists, PSNI numbers, the York Street interchange, LGBT rights, and Brexit.

Northern Ireland will be aligning with England and Wales by introducing automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This is called "Turing's Law" and will allow both posthumous pardons for those who have passed away and applications for living men convicted of such offences. The motion will be presented to the assembly for approval and aims to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men as their counterparts in England and Wales.

Yvonne Muir set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race, finishing second with a time of 4:19.12. This time surpasses Yvonne Murray's 1994 record and places her second on the British all-time list. Muir is now the holder of both the Scottish 1500m and mile records, and hopes to secure a spot on the British Olympic team in Rio.
The passage lists 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the best water quality.

Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, suspects in the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko, had no personal motive for the crime. UK officials believe the Russian state was responsible for the poisoning, citing the presence of polonium-210, a radioactive substance, in Litvinenko's tea.  The evidence suggests Russian state involvement, but it doesn't mean Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order. Possible motives include Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his public criticism of Putin. The inquiry heard that the suspects left a "trail of polonium" and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them.  Attempts to extradite the suspects have failed and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke. This decision was made after Clarke announced his retirement following Australia's loss in the Ashes. Smith, 26, has already captained the team in three Tests and is considered a talented and highly regarded player. David Warner has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary issues, and is expected to step up as a senior leader. The new leadership team will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, is a strong supporter of LGBT+ rights. He believes in equal marriage and wants to extend the rights of transgender people. He voted against the Equality Bill in 2007, citing concerns about individual liberties, but maintains he supports equal access under the law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Accord Healthcare is taking over the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, Newcastle. This move is expected to create new jobs, with many of them going to former Sanofi employees. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company and the investment is seen as a positive boost to the local economy.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the local authority. Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, Monaghan and Sutherland are retiring under a voluntary redundancy scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, believes this indicates the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff. He expects further departures in the coming months.

Michael Martin has decided to focus on non-road racing events, specifically classics and oddball races, after a difficult year with mechanical problems on his Honda Fireblade bike. He will not be racing in the North West 200 or the Ulster Grand Prix. He cited the TT as a "bloody disaster" and the bike's uncompetitiveness as reasons for his decision.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The APC secured victories in the north and Lagos, while the PDP held on to the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The PDP lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and control of Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram. Despite these losses, the PDP won eight governorships. The APC's victory is significant as it relegates the PDP to a regional party, and raises concerns about potential disruption of oil production due to militant groups. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were relatively peaceful. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild itself under a new leader.

The passage discusses allegations against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, for their role in contributing to the annual haze caused by agricultural fires in Southeast Asia. 

Mighty, a US-based environmental group, accuses Olam and Temasek of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices, potentially contributing to the haze. Olam claims to have a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and has released the names of 14 suppliers, but acknowledges the vetting process takes time. Temasek, while denying the allegations, acknowledges the importance of no-burn policies and urges oil palm companies to follow them. 

The passage also highlights the broader issues within the palm oil industry, including accusations of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and the burning of plantations. It notes the conflict between environmental groups and palm oil executives, and the challenge of enforcing environmental standards on third-party suppliers.
A new law allowing dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors led a restaurant to start serving "puppy platters".

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt for Derby County due to a knee injury, while David Nugent could return after missing the last game. Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a starting position after scoring a late goal in the previous match.

Pakistan lifted its ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The ban was lifted due to Google's local launch and the PTA's confirmation that all ISPs must provide access to YouTube. While the government can request content removal, YouTube states that it will only remove content that violates its community guidelines and that it will review requests for content removal.  The ban was imposed in 2012 after the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded, leading to protests and violence.

The upcoming FIFA presidential election is facing controversy due to Domenico Scala, a member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, who is Swiss-Italian and shares nationality with a candidate. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian FA, claims this constitutes a conflict of interest and wants Scala to withdraw.  Scala argues that there is no such provision in the regulations and that he withdrew from the 2015 election due to the Swiss candidate being the incumbent. Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't step down.  The election is scheduled for February 26th and will be held in Zurich.

Two men, Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning. The cause of death is believed to be a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source.  The Health and Safety Executive is investigating the incident.

This passage details the controversies surrounding Tunisia and Morocco's participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. 

* **Tunisia:** They faced expulsion from the tournament due to complaints against Caf, but were able to participate after apologizing. 
* **Morocco:** They were initially banned from the 2015 tournament due to their refusal to host, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced the fine.
* **Both countries:** They are now preparing for the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. 
* **Key takeaway:** The passage highlights the controversies surrounding both countries' participation in the tournament, but ultimately emphasizes their participation and the positive outlook for the future of African football.

Chelsea won their match against Manchester City 3-1, but the game ended with two players from City being sent off. Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, and Fernandinho received a three-match ban for his part in a scuffle.  Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea player, will not face any further action.

This passage describes a new pilot program in Wales aimed at early detection of cancer. The program, based in Cynon and Castell-nedd, focuses on families with potential cancer risk but without clear symptoms.  The program aims to improve diagnosis by providing families with a quicker and more efficient process.  The program is based on the experience of Denmarc, where the cancer diagnosis rate has increased.  The program will be expanded to other areas of Wales if successful.

England won the third Test against Pakistan by a large margin, securing a second-biggest win in terms of runs. Joe Root was the standout performer, scoring 254 and 71 in the two innings. He was named man of the match and praised for his controlled and disciplined batting. England's bowling was also effective, dismissing Pakistan for 234 in the second innings.  Pakistan struggled on the pitch, scoring only 63 and 70 overs in their two innings.  The series is still very much alive, with Pakistan needing to regroup and improve their performance in the next Test.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand. Rob Howley is part of the backroom team, and  Alun Wyn Jones will be the interim head coach for the tour. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour.  The involvement of Welsh coaches is expected to benefit the national team and Welsh rugby as a whole.

Southampton won the match against Hull City with a score of 2-1.  The match was initially dominated by Southampton, with Charlie Austin's penalty giving them an early lead. However, Hull City fought back with a quickfire double in the second half, thanks to goals from Snodgrass and Dawson.  Despite Southampton's dominance in the first half, Hull City's resilience and a string of saves from David Marshall kept them in the game.  The win ends Hull City's six-game losing streak and provides a much-needed boost for the team.

A motorcyclist died in a crash on the B1191 near Thornton, Lincolnshire at 14:15 BST. The driver of the tractor was uninjured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 and A158. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, citing the need to end the political turmoil ahead of early elections. This move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who view it as illegal and a threat to Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. The crisis began in 2015 with the release of recordings showing ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing these recordings, accusing the government of corruption and other illegal activities. The government denies the accusations and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilize the country.

Swansea is in a difficult situation after Bob Bradley's sacking. They are looking for a new manager to help them stay in the Premier League, with Paul Clement being their top choice.  The club believes they have lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and are concerned about their ability to stay up.  However, the current squad is good enough to stay up, and the new signings are reminded of the club's history and the importance of staying in the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge won against Leyton Orient, securing their promotion to the National League. Despite a 2-0 lead by Orient, Dagenham's Armand Gnanduillet scored the winning goal. This victory keeps Leyton Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham's manager, John Still, acknowledged the team's struggles this season, particularly their poor goal difference and lack of discipline. Leyton Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, expressed his commitment to the club and the need to win games to secure a play-off spot.

Steven Gerrard, a former Liverpool captain and player, will become a youth coach at his former club in February. He is eager to pursue a managerial career and is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching license. Gerrard has a wealth of experience, having won multiple trophies with Liverpool and played professionally for 19 years.
Alloa Athletic won against Morton with a score of 3-1.  McManus scored two goals, while Forbes and McAusland also scored for their respective teams.

The passage details the findings of Ofsted, which has uncovered evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed Birmingham schools. These schools were suspected of operating illegally.  The investigation, which has visited 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities, has uncovered potential risks of abuse and radicalization.  The government is considering stricter regulations for schools teaching for more than 6-8 hours a week and is consulting on plans to prosecute unregistered schools.  The investigation will be expanded to include other religious groups operating similar illegal schools.

Lilliard Gin, a new distillery in the Scottish Borders, is set to open at the Born in the Borders visitor centre.  The distillery is unique in its small scale, using a small production still and operating from a cowshed.  The gin is inspired by the local landscape and its strong female production team, named after a legendary Borders heroine, Lilliard.  The distillery aims to capture the local flavour palette and "terroir" of the region.  This new distillery is a natural addition to the existing Scottish Borders Brewery on the site.

Gary Green, 51, of Bradburn Road, Wakefield, was driving a tractor and killed Harry Whitlam, 51, on private land at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds in August 2013. Green was over twice the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the accident. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) investigated the incident and found Green's actions were reckless.

Luis Suarez has had his four-month ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS).  He can now train and play in friendlies, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities.  While he still has to serve the remaining eight games of his ban in competitive international matches, his competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be in the El Clasico against Real Madrid on October 26th.  The CAS ruling acknowledged that the initial ban was excessive and that Suarez should be allowed to train and participate in football-related activities.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race carrying Vytautas Kirkliauskas's wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved a 380-meter course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols.  The winners will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The government is replacing the paper tax disc system with an electronic system in October 2014. This change will likely lead to a reduction in the number of refunds received and may require job role changes and training for DVLA employees. The government plans to redeploy employees to other areas of the business to minimize job losses.

Hungary's government is facing pressure from the EU to withdraw three controversial laws. These laws include restrictions on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law that could close the Central European University. Hungary's foreign minister, Szijjarto, has stated that the laws are within Hungary's national competence and that the EU should not interfere. Poland has also pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU is concerned about Hungary's policies, including the forced housing of asylum seekers in shipping containers, and has warned that action will be taken if the laws are not withdrawn.

The film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast" will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and Josh Gad will voice LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the film.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and writer for the Sunday Times, passed away suddenly at the age of 60. He was known for his witty and fearless writing style, his unique voice, and his controversial opinions. Gill was diagnosed with multiple cancers and had been battling the illness for some time. He was a beloved colleague and friend to many, including his editor Martin Ivens, who described him as the "heart and soul" of the paper.  Gill's final column, about his diagnosis, will be published in tomorrow's Sunday Times. He was a celebrated writer who had a long and successful career, known for his unique style and his ability to make people laugh and think.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was attacked in Ulan Bator while performing in a red deel embroidered with a swastika. The attack involved being hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, calling local press reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar's father stated his son suffered serious injuries, including a damaged brain, and the swastika is a traditional symbol in Mongolia predating the Nazi era. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested and the case is under investigation.

Plane Stupid activists staged a protest against the airport expansion plans on Monday, resulting in charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST and will be reviewed by the Metropolitan Police.

Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored a century (101) and helped his team reach 220, despite a slow wicket and early short bowling.  Gloucestershire struggled to bat, with their bowlers taking wickets regularly.  The day ended with the score balanced, leaving both teams with a chance to win.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested for making threats to shoot police officers. He admitted to planning a false police report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he intended to carry out the attack while intoxicated. Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail for firearms offences at the time of the incident. The Hope Line Crisis Centre, which provides support to those in crisis, was involved in the case.

Yorkshire were aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 after losing to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals. They had a strong start with a partnership between Davies and Foakes, but dropped catches and a three-wicket burst by Meaker turned the game around. Despite a valiant effort from Bresnan and Waite, Yorkshire fell short of their target, losing by a significant margin.

A 56ft trawler experienced a pump failure, causing water to flood the vessel. The crew contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST, and the RNLI lifeboat crew provided assistance by towing the boat to Holyhead.

Nicola Muir, a Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss the 2022 Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships and will be focusing on her final year of university studies.  She plans to target the World Indoor Championships in March and hopes to run in Birmingham.

Liverpool are struggling this season and are not performing at the level required to challenge for the title. This is due to a number of factors, including:

* **Lack of goals:** The departure of Luis Suarez and the injury to Daniel Sturridge has left Liverpool's attack lacking in firepower.
* **Lack of intensity:** Liverpool are not pressing teams as aggressively as they did last season, leading to a lack of goals and a more passive style of play.
* **Defensive issues:** Despite spending money on new players, Liverpool's defense is still not performing at a high level.
* **Set-piece struggles:** Liverpool's set-piece ability has dropped significantly, which has impacted their overall goal-scoring.

Steven Gerrard is facing a mental battle to secure a long-term future with Liverpool. He is still a key player for the team, but his age and the recent disappointment against Chelsea may affect his future at Anfield.

A new £45 million facility in Kilmarnock, Scotland, will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The campus will be named after William McIlvanney, a renowned Scottish writer who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. The council plans to honor McIlvanney's legacy by naming the facility after him.  McIlvanney was a prolific writer, known for his "Tartan Noir" novels and other works, and was also a respected poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

A sea mine, possibly British from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near Gourock's swimming pool.  The mine caused an evacuation of three streets and a half-mile exclusion zone at sea.  The evacuation was precautionary, and there is no immediate danger to the community. Experts are working to move the mine to a safer location before dealing with it.

The UK government has cut funding for 10 Olympic and Paralympic sports, including badminton, cycling, and judo.  The funding cuts are part of a £345m investment in 31 sports for Tokyo 2020, with a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals.  Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, is the only sport to have its funding cut after achieving a podium finish. UK Sport claims the cuts are necessary to prioritize medal potential and prevent underperformance at the Games.  However, some sports, like basketball and handball, argue that the cuts are unfair and that UK Sport should take responsibility for developing high-performance teams.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks will be built on the site of three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's conservation area. The project received support from 246 residents but was opposed by English Heritage and 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society. The council approved the development, citing the need to improve tourism and the need to replace outdated buildings.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally beaten in Brecon, Wales, after being attacked outside a bar. Jake Vallely, who was on a drinking binge, was found guilty of the murder.  His friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of any involvement in the attack.  The attack was captured on CCTV footage, showing Vallely punching and beating Boyd until he was unconscious.  Boyd's family described him as a loving and loyal person with a promising future cut short by the attack.  The community of Brecon has expressed their grief and condemned the violence.

Barnet Council's chief executive, Andrew Travers, resigned after a polling day error that prevented many voters from casting their ballots.  The error, which saw voters turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the electoral register, led to an independent investigation.  Travers, who has been chief executive for three and a half years, stated his belief in the borough's future despite the issues.  The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes, but voters questioned the fairness of the election.  A council review, expected to conclude by the end of May, will examine the registration process and its suitability for future elections, including the EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where both teams had chances.  Gateshead's goals came from a free-kick by Josh Gillies and a header by Ryan Bowman. Wrexham's goal was scored by Manny Smith.  The match was a back-and-forth affair, with Wrexham having a strong first half but struggling in the second.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic well-being of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway topped the list, while Afghanistan ranked last, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb is a project aiming to create a global broadband network using a constellation of satellites. The project will involve at least 600 satellites initially, with the goal of reaching every corner of the globe. Airbus, a major partner in the project, is developing new assembly lines to manufacture the satellites at a lower cost and higher volume. The first satellites are scheduled for launch in April 2021, with a planned increase in launch cadence over the next few years. The project faces challenges related to debris mitigation, but OneWeb is committed to de-orbiting its satellites within two years and implementing measures to prevent collisions. The project is also expected to have a significant impact on the satellite industry, with Airbus and OneWeb planning to manufacture satellites for other companies.

The UK government has increased Scotland's spending by £390 million for the next year. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010, along with the recent spending review, will result in a 12.5% reduction in its discretionary budget by 2019-20.  Mr Swinney emphasizes that these cuts are a result of the UK government's austerity measures and that Scotland will need to make tough choices to protect key priorities like schools, hospitals, and the police service. He also highlights the positive outcomes achieved by the Scottish government in recent years, such as increased police presence, lower crime rates, and improved education and healthcare. The UK government, on the other hand, argues that the increased spending is a result of the UK economy's stability and that Scotland is receiving a better deal than the constitutional alternative proposed by the Scottish government.

This passage discusses the lack of accessible changing facilities for people with disabilities, particularly those who require more space and assistance than standard accessible toilets can provide.  

The main points are:

* **The need for Changing Places toilets:**  These are larger, more accessible toilets designed for people with severe disabilities who need assistance with changing.  
* **The current situation:**  There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but many people with disabilities still lack access to these facilities.
* **The impact on families:**  Families with disabled children often face stressful situations when trying to find suitable changing facilities, leading to feelings of isolation and anxiety.
* **Campaigning for change:**  Campaigners are calling for Changing Places facilities to be made compulsory in new buildings, such as shopping centres, cinemas, and sports stadiums.
* **Benefits of Changing Places:**  These facilities allow people with disabilities to participate in everyday activities and feel more included in society. 
* **Challenges to implementation:**  Businesses face logistical and financial barriers to installing Changing Places toilets, especially in existing buildings.


The passage highlights the importance of accessible changing facilities and the need for change in building regulations to ensure everyone has equal access to public spaces

A group of Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint against McDonald's with the European Commission, alleging the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. McDonald's claims it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and that this approach has been successful. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions. The European Commission will now study the complaint and has the power to launch an investigation if it finds evidence of wrongdoing. The consumer organizations claim that McDonald's contracts prevent franchisees from switching to competitors and that they lease premises at above-market rates, leading to higher prices and poorer consumer choice.

Joshua Martin, a 13-year-old from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve.  He was due to have an appendix operation, but doctors discovered a large primary cancer and five smaller growths.  A social media campaign started by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is a pastor, using the hashtag #prayforjosh has gone viral, garnering support from people all over the world.  A mystery donor paid for a billboard in Holywood to display the hashtag, and Josh's classmates are using the hashtag on Twitter to support him.

The UK government is planning to close Brecon Barracks in Wales and relocate troops to other locations. This decision has been met with strong opposition from local MP Chris Davies, who argues it disrespects the barracks' long history and will negatively impact the local economy.  The closure of Brecon Barracks is part of a wider restructuring of the UK military estate, with a new specialist light infantry centre being created at St Athan. Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire will also close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report examining the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry following Brexit. While the industry is small, it is important to the UK economy and many in the industry believe Brexit will offer opportunities for greater control and independence. However, the report highlights potential challenges, including the need to maintain access to EU markets and the potential for trade-offs in negotiations. The report also suggests that the UK should retain elements of the Common Fisheries Policy, including scientific advice on quotas and the need for international cooperation.  Despite these challenges, the report acknowledges that Brexit could lead to a more sustainable and equitable fishing industry.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA employee, leaked documents revealing the extent of the US National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance program, known as Prism. The program grants the NSA access to vast amounts of data from major technology companies, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and others. This data includes chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and social media activity. The NSA has access to this data through "backdoor" access to servers of these companies, which process and store the information. While the NSA claims this helps keep Americans secure, experts question the program's true effectiveness and argue that it may be more akin to a "catflap" than a "backdoor."  The program raises concerns about privacy and data protection, as the US government can access data stored in other countries, including those of EU citizens.  The US government argues that this is necessary to prevent terrorism, but privacy advocates and experts are concerned about the potential for abuse and the lack of transparency surrounding the program.

OpenAI, a venture backed by prominent figures like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, aims to develop AI for positive human impact. While some experts warn of AI's potential threat to humanity, OpenAI emphasizes its focus on benefiting society and avoiding financial gain. The venture plans to distribute AI technology widely and safely, with a small portion of its funding allocated in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a British soldier who was seriously injured in Afghanistan, is carrying the Olympic torch. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits him to 5,000 friends. Despite this, he has been buoyed by the support and friendship he has received. Parkinson is dedicated to his rehabilitation, spending 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and is also actively raising money for military charities. His mother has reported an increase in the amount of support they have received, including mail addressed to him and a surge in email traffic.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased for the first time since 1993.  The percentage of Americans without health insurance also decreased.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, joined Lancashire in 2013 and has a contract with the club until 2019. He is known for his fast-paced batting, scoring England's three fastest ODI centuries. Buttler is a valuable asset to the team, both for his talent and his experience. He recently played in the T20 Blast final and is expected to return to Lancashire for a home game against Durham.

The four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall) are being sold by the UK government.  The government aims to award at least one of the ships to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity.  A final decision is expected in the spring.  There are bids from interested parties, and the government is considering various options to maximize financial return for the taxpayer.  The frigates were originally designed for anti-submarine warfare but evolved into powerful surface combatant ships.

Fiji has experienced a history of political instability and international isolation due to racial and political tensions.  This has led to several coups, including a 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians, a 2000 coup led by George Speight, and a 2006 military takeover. These events caused economic harm and damaged Fiji's international reputation.  However, following free elections in 2014, Fiji was reinstated as a member of the Commonwealth and its diplomatic ties were restored.  Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with a history of segregation and limited mixing between the groups.  The economy is diverse, relying on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, but faces persistent trade and budget deficits, leading to high levels of aid dependency.

Syria missed its deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile. The Syrian government blames attacks on the shipment for the delay, claiming the second shipment was intercepted by terrorist groups.  The government denies reports of rebels seizing control of Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre report the prison is now under rebel control.  The US is concerned about the slow progress of the chemical weapons destruction process and has called on Syria to fulfill its commitment.  The OPCW, overseeing the destruction, has acknowledged security concerns as a factor in the delay.

The Booker Prize shortlist for 2023 includes authors from various countries, with a focus on English-language works.  The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall.  The shortlisted novels cover diverse themes and styles, including a futuristic love story, a novel about a Renaissance artist, a story about atheism, a love story set against the backdrop of World War Two, and a family saga set in 1960s Calcutta.  "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" by Karen Joy Fowler is the best-selling book on the list.  The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling and includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner.  The prize is worth £2,500 and a specially bound edition of the shortlisted book.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his name being published in the media in England and Wales. The ban was in place to protect his privacy, as he has young children and a spouse who is also in the public eye. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but he argues he has a right to privacy. The Court of Appeal initially prevented his identification in publications, but the Sun on Sunday appealed this decision. The Court of Appeal judges ruled that PJS is unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction due to the widespread dissemination of the allegations online.

Fosse Park, a shopping center near the M1, was purchased in August for Â£345.5 million. The new owners, Crown Estates, plan to improve parking, traffic flow, and the overall appearance of the park. They aim to enhance the common areas and facilities to create a more appealing experience for visitors.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" was initially banned in Malaysia for a "gay moment" but was later approved with a minor edit. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film but with a minor edit concerning a gay moment in the film. The film's release date is yet to be announced. Local cinema chains are offering refunds for customers who purchased tickets in advance.

In Southampton, landlords of properties with more than three unrelated tenants need a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license.  The cost of the license is a concern for many landlords, despite the potential fine of up to £20,000.  There are estimated to be 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the city.  The licensing scheme aims to improve living conditions for tenants and address the shortage of affordable housing.  While landlords have generally cooperated, a small number have resisted obtaining the license.

The passage describes the current political situation in Ireland, focusing on the difficulty of forming a government.  Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin, leaders of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil respectively, are seeking to avoid a second election.  While Fianna Fáil is willing to support a minority government, they will not support a program for government.  A key sticking point is the issue of water charges, with Fianna Fáil advocating for their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting a role for them.  The passage also notes the current composition of the Dáil (Irish Parliament) and the ongoing struggle to elect a Taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry traveling to Valencia, caught fire on Tuesday afternoon while 27km from Mallorca. The fire started on a car deck and caused injuries to at least three people. Passengers and crew were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship, the Puglia. The ferry is expected to arrive back in Palma de Mallorca soon. The Balearic Islands port authority warns that the Sorrento may sink in its current position.

The UK general election saw a record high voter turnout of 68.7%, with 46.8 million people registered to vote.  Concerns remain about duplicate applications, with a significant proportion of applications likely to be duplicates, estimated between 30% and 70%. The Electoral Commission highlighted the issue, urging for clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to prevent duplicate applications. While there were no confirmed cases of people voting twice, the issue was taken seriously, and anyone with information should contact the police. The Electoral Commission also recommended a system for registered voters to choose which seat they will vote in at future elections.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, is believed to have committed suicide while serving a 30+ year prison sentence for assault convictions. He was known for his success in the 1990s, but struggled with legal issues and personal problems throughout his life, including a conviction for assault against a former girlfriend and a death of his cellmate.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a ram who is officially classified as a soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. He received his promotion for "good behaviour" and is the 30th in a line of mascots dating back to the Indian Mutiny War.  He joined the regiment in 2014 and has his own army number, receives rations, and takes holidays during the mating season.  He has also participated in public events like switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in a thrilling Europa League match, overcoming a 2-0 deficit. The victory was a testament to Liverpool's resilience and belief, fueled by manager Jürgen Klopp's inspiring leadership and the passionate support of the Anfield crowd. The match was a display of high-quality football, with both teams showcasing their skills.  The victory was a significant step for Liverpool in their pursuit of a Champions League spot, and it marked a turning point in the season for the team.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, UK government officials discussed plans for transparency and collaboration with devolved administrations (Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland) regarding Brexit negotiations.  UK government officials aim to hold monthly meetings to share analysis and allow for two-way information flow.  They emphasized the importance of working together to secure the best deal for the UK.  However, Scottish government representative Mr. Russell expressed concern over the lack of clarity on UK government intentions regarding the EU market access and the UK's future relationship with the single market. He called for greater transparency and clarity from the UK government.

This passage describes a study examining the health of cloned sheep, specifically focusing on their potential for developing age-related diseases. The study, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, involves monitoring the health of 13 cloned sheep, including four clones from the same original ewe as Dolly the sheep. The researchers are investigating whether these animals age normally and if the cloning process itself contributes to premature aging. The study focuses on three common age-related conditions: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could have significant implications for the future of cloning, are expected to be published next week.

Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Trainer John Gosden will send her to the French Oaks in Chantilly, while stablemates Enable and Coronet will compete in the Epsom Oaks. Trainer William Haggas's Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes. Trainer John Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will decide whether to run him based on the course conditions.

The British pound has experienced significant volatility in recent days, falling against major currencies like the dollar, euro, and yen. This decline is attributed to a combination of factors, including falling Remain vote probabilities, global economic concerns, and increased uncertainty surrounding the Brexit referendum.  While the Leave campaign argues that the pound's decline is a normal reaction to the referendum, experts predict further volatility as polls continue to show a tight race between the two campaigns.  The uncertainty surrounding Brexit has also impacted Asian stock markets, with the Nikkei and Hong Kong indices experiencing significant drops.  However, the UK's trade deficit has narrowed in April, potentially benefiting UK exporters.

Braintree Town are currently sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots.  They lost to Barrow in a tough match after a long journey.  Despite the loss, manager, Cowley, remains positive about the team's performance and their journey in the league. He acknowledges the challenge of being a part-time team and emphasizes their determination to embrace the competition.

The passage discusses the controversial shift in planning power from the Planning Service to local councils in Northern Ireland.  

**Key points:**

* **Shift in power:**  Local councils will make planning decisions, replacing the current system where the Planning Service and local councils handle applications.
* **Potential benefits:**  Local councils can develop community-specific plans and potentially improve urban regeneration.
* **Concerns:**  There are concerns that this could lead to discrimination in housing allocation and favoritism towards certain communities.
* **Transparency:**  Environmental groups like Friends of the Earth advocate for strict enforcement of a code of conduct to ensure fairness and transparency in planning decisions.
* **Political influence:**  There are worries about the potential for developers and political parties to influence planning decisions, potentially leading to a "laissez-faire" system.
* **Political donations:**  The passage mentions the potential impact of political donations on the new system and the need for greater transparency in this area. 


The passage highlights the potential benefits and concerns surrounding the transfer of planning power to local councils in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an airgun, sustaining injuries to her shoulder and back leg. The incident occurred in NiddryView, Winchburgh, and the Scottish SPCA is investigating. The owner, Sarah Nisbett, is upset and believes the shooter is a "sick person." The Scottish SPCA's Chief Superintendent Mike Flynn believes the Scottish government should implement airgun licensing to prevent future incidents.  Last year, a consultation on airgun licensing was launched, with a majority of respondents opposing the plan.

Liverpool signed Belgian striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a reported fee of £32.5 million. The club triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract, making him their seventh summer signing. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk in 2012. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers hopes Benteke will revive the team's attack after a lackluster season last year. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will thrive at Anfield and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is excited about Benteke's potential to lead the team's attack.

The study found that while tablet computers are becoming increasingly common in schools (68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools), there is no clear evidence that they lead to academic improvement.  However, teachers report a positive impact from using tablets, particularly in motivating disengaged students and increasing family involvement.  The study also found that tablet computers are used extensively at home, with a quarter of secondary pupils describing themselves as "internet addicts."  The study suggests that touch-screen computers are particularly useful for helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read.  Overall, the study highlights the growing role of technology in education and the need for schools to adapt to the digital world.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs that capture the lives of children in Liverpool over 100 years. The photographs showcase the evolution of childhood in the city, highlighting both the joys and hardships of growing up. The exhibition spans from the 1880s to the 1990s and includes images of children playing, as well as those working.  Curator Kay Jones selected the final 25 images after carefully reviewing hundreds of photographs and postcards from the National Museums Liverpool's collections.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow and joined their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, has joined Plymouth Argyle from Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps.  Keating was recommended by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams. The Gulls are currently in a precarious position in the league.

Bolivia's new law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, aiming to address poverty. The law sets a 30-year sentence for child homicide and aims to eradicate extreme poverty. While the International Labour Organisation (ILO) opposes child labor for those under 15, Bolivia's law is based on its unique needs and characteristics. The ILO is currently reviewing the law to determine if it violates international regulations.

50-year-old actress, O'Donnell, experienced a heart attack after helping a woman in her car. She initially self-treated with aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day who inserted a stent due to a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell's blog post details her experience, including the "widow maker" type of attack and a warning to women to listen to their bodies and call emergency services.  Her talk show, "The Rosie Show," was cancelled in March.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 16-year-old boy from Harrow, was stabbed to death in an alleyway in Kenton, London, after a party he was attending. He was stabbed during a later scuffle after being invited to the party, which appeared to be well-run. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been bailed. A third boy, aged 14, is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes a new approach to cancer diagnosis in Denmark, aiming to improve survival rates. The key changes include:

* **Fast-track routes:** For patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers, there are fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes with strict time targets.
* **Diagnosis centres:**  These centres, located at existing hospitals and clinics, provide a range of tests and scans to diagnose patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose.
* **"Yes-no" centres:** These centres offer simple tests or scans for patients with minor symptoms, allowing for quick identification of any problems.

These changes have led to better organization of patient diagnosis within existing resources and improved survival rates. Denmark is catching up to the leading European countries in cancer diagnosis and treatment.

The UK government has transferred the responsibility of enforcing estate agent laws from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to Powys council. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to handle complaints and issue warnings or bans against agents who violate the Estate Agents Act. Local authorities will still handle complaints, but will refer cases to Powys if they believe the law has been broken.

The NHS is facing staffing shortages, particularly in junior doctors and GPs. The Nuffield Trust reviewed ways to reshape the workforce and found opportunities for nurses to take on more responsibilities, including filling in for doctors and pharmacists. This shift is driven by the increasing demand for long-term care and the need for more staff in other areas. While the report highlights potential benefits, there are concerns about the impact on doctor training and funding for training courses. Unions warn against using this as a quick fix for the chronic shortages of nurses and other health workers.

A crash on Lower Bristol Road in Bath caused a road closure at Rackfield Place, impacting commuters and bus services during rush hour. The closure lasted from 03:00 GMT to 14:00 GMT. Investigations are underway to determine the cause of the collision. First Bus services were disrupted but are gradually returning to normal.

The Swansea tidal lagoon project is facing controversy over its potential impact on fish populations. NRW, the Welsh environment regulator, estimates the lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually. TLP, the project developer, disputes these figures, claiming they lack scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of only 2% fish mortality. The project is being reviewed by UK government ministers, with the Welsh government supportive.

Northern Ireland is establishing a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, modeled after Scotland's Food and Drink, to improve coordination and support the sector's growth. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will provide strategic leadership and direction for both government and private sector marketing activities.  While the move is welcomed by the Agriculture Minister, Michelle O'Neill, she acknowledges potential implications for other organizations, including her own department, and plans to discuss the plans with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is planting 40,000 native trees in Brackfield Wood, Faughan Valley, as a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in World War I. The project, part of a larger four-year program, aims to create a living memorial and wildlife haven.  The public is invited to participate in the planting, with saplings provided by the charity.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin". The book tackles domestic violence and honor crime and is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome.  Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career writing about the female private investigator VI Warshawski.  Paretsky is considered a game changer for female writers and helped establish Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers.

New Zealand cricketer Santner broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, missing out on a chance to contribute to the team's success.  He is returning to Worcestershire for the 2017 season and hopes to make up for lost time.  Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a millionaire, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. The coroner ruled his death an unlawful killing, citing the driver's intoxication and the car's stolen license plates.  His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was suspected of involvement in his death as she attempted to claim his assets shortly after his death.  Ziuzina was found to have sold his belongings, moved funds from his bank account, and had an affair with a Ukrainian man.  The case remains active but not actively pursued by Ukrainian police.

Charlie Fearns, a young boy from Merseyside, needs a second T-Cell transplant at Seattle Children's Hospital due to a failed previous treatment. His mother, Sophie, states that the treatment is unavailable in the UK and that Charlie's health has deteriorated after three relapses. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, providing financial relief for his family. The family is grateful for the donation and is awaiting the start date of the treatment, which is expected to begin soon.

The passage discusses Apple's new security measures to prevent the theft of intimate photos from iCloud.  Third-party software was used to access iCloud data, but Apple's new two-step verification system, requiring a four-digit code or recovery key, now blocks access if the code is not entered.  While Apple previously offered this feature, it was not enabled for iCloud backups.  The passage also highlights concerns about the recovery key's potential for loss or theft, and the need for stronger password practices.  Experts suggest making two-factor authentication the default option for increased security.

Billericay Town is an Isthmian League Premier Division club currently in eighth place. They have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has invested £10,000 a week.  Former England international Paul Konchesky was signed in March.  Wright, a 30-year-old, is set to become a club director in a deal that will see him acquire 20% of the club.

Mr. Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into warehouse practices.  The Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Iain Wright, is reviewing worker rights and minimum wage enforcement.  Mr. Ashley has been invited to a public meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook, but has not accepted any of the offered dates.  The committee has the right to take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons, if Mr. Ashley does not respond.  Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment.

The passage describes a report, "Putin. War," written by opposition figures in Russia to expose the involvement of Russian troops and equipment in the conflict in Ukraine. The report, based on existing media reports, argues that President Putin is waging war for his own political gain. It presents evidence of Russian soldiers and generals directing battles, volunteer soldiers receiving salaries, and the significant financial cost of the conflict. Despite the report's existence, it faces challenges in publication and distribution due to fear from publishers and the public's acceptance of the Russian government's narrative. The report's potential impact remains uncertain, similar to the fate of previous reports by Boris Nemtsov, which failed to spark widespread protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. A post-mortem revealed he died from head injuries. Two people, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman, were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

The passage discusses the UK government's Article 50 letter, which mentions Wales and the transfer of powers back to the UK. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed his disappointment that he wasn't consulted on the letter's drafting and believes the UK government is not respecting the devolved administrations. Alun Cairns, the Welsh Secretary, defended the government's actions, stating they are acting in the best interests of the whole UK. The passage also highlights the uncertainty surrounding which powers will be devolved and whether the accompanying financial support will be maintained.

On Friday night in Newry, two cars were damaged in an incident involving police officers. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his disappointment and called the attacks "mindless." The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that officers were performing their duties when they were attacked and urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. His lawyer claims the accusations are false and a form of extortion. The company's court filing alleges Mr. Charney violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy and provides evidence of his inappropriate emails and racially derogatory remarks. The board believes hiring Mr. Charney would be too risky for the company and its shareholders.  A restraining order was recently granted to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company.

Great Britain will play Greece in London on August 17th at the Copper Box, as part of their preparation for the FIBA EuroBasket 2017. This will be Britain's only home game before the tournament, which starts in Istanbul, Turkey, in September.  The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 5:30 PM to 7:30 PM BST.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the iPhone's launch and its impact on technology and society.  

**Key points:**

* **Early skepticism:** The author initially dismissed the iPhone's hype, believing it was just a novelty.
* **iPhone's revolutionary impact:** The author later recognized the iPhone's transformative power, comparing it to the Model T Ford in its impact on daily life.
* **Revolutionized photography:** The iPhone's user interface made mobile photography accessible and changed how people viewed and shared photos.
* **Beyond the hype:** While other companies like Amazon and Google are innovating with AI, the iPhone marked the beginning of the mobile connected era. 
* **Historical significance:** The author acknowledges the iPhone's historical significance and its impact on technology and society.

Seven cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire have died from ingesting antifreeze. The most recent death was a seven-month-old cat named Meereen, who died after consuming antifreeze and being taken to the vet. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. They are urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially as it is the time of year when antifreeze is used in cars.

Despite the Syriza government implementing austerity measures demanded by creditors, Greece's tourism industry is thriving. However, there is a lack of public protest against these measures, which may be due to the upcoming announcement of a new bailout deal. This deal, which will likely involve significant concessions from the government, is expected to provide Greece with €86 billion in new credit. However, the new bailout may not be enough to alleviate the economic squeeze on Greece, and the country's debt burden remains unsustainable. The success of the new bailout hinges on the government's ability to offer hope of better times ahead, and for creditors to consider debt forgiveness.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in EastEnders for Barbara Windsor's final episodes.  He will reunite with Steve McFadden, who plays Phil Mitchell, to say goodbye to their mother, Peggy, who is dying from cancer.  This will be a chance for the Mitchell brothers to face their grief and reunite with their mother one last time.
